On Monday 21 February 2005 15:35, Pico Geyer wrote:
> Thanks Andrew.
>
>
>
> The example you provided was a great help.
>
> I have another related question though:
>
> If the class that your are creating a wrapper for (in our example
> NetworkInterface) has static methods, your forced to leave these static
> methods out of the interface because you can't declare a static method in a
> interface. This would mean that these methods can't be included in your
> mock object.
>
> I would imagine that this is a bad thing. Is there a way to work around
> this problem?

Use a non-static method in the interface whose implementation (in some
concrete class) is to call the original class's static method (plus 
whatever mocking calls you require).

-- 
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
